title-group.article-title: Employing volcanic tuff minerals in interior architecture design to reduce microbial contaminants and airborne fungal carcinogens of indoor environments

abstract.p: Indoor volatile organic compounds (VOCs) have posed significant risks to human health since people have both shifted to a life spent, for the most part, indoors. Further, changes in materials used in the construction of buildings, furnishings, and tools either leak or encourage the production of VOCs. Whether these enclosed areas are residences, hospitals or workplaces (specifically composting facilities or closed farm buildings for raising livestock), VOCs can rise to levels that threaten people’s health. VOCs can either originate from phenolic and benzene-like compounds in building materials and office furniture or from molds (fungi) growing inside improperly ventilated or sealed buildings. Regardless of the source, exposure to VOCs could lead to significant health concerns from sick-building syndrome, ‘leukemia houses,’ in-hospital fungemia cases or occupation-associated cancer epidemics due to aflatoxicosis. Innovative 21st-century building materials could offer solutions to these challenges. We propose that volcanic materials, clays and minerals (volcanic tuff, modified clay montmorillonite and mineral clinoptilolite), in their original or chemically modified form, could act like synthetic lungs in building walls, breathing and filtering VOCs, and thus limiting human exposure to disease.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Humans spend much of their time indoors in buildings that contain and process the air they breathe. For example, Americans spend about 90% of their time indoors, with 65% of that time spent in their homes. Whether a building is a residence or a workplace, proper design is crucial for the health of its occupants. As we discuss in detail below, fungi constitutes a considerable health hazard in all structures. Therefore, walls of the home, workplace and hospitals of the 21st century should contain specific building materials that hinder the growth and/or absorb toxins produced by fungi. The walls of the 21st century hospital should also be bacteria blocking. We propose that volcanic clays and minerals (volcanic tuff, modified clay montmorillonite and mineral clinoptilolite) constitute a proper choice in covering wall surfaces that would provide both antibacterial (Brunet de Courrsou, 2002; Haydel et al., 2008; Nováková, 1977) and antifungal (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986a, b) protection to the building’s occupants.

sec.title: Occurrence and activity of mycotoxins in bioaerosols
sec.p: There are two routes for mycotoxins to become airborne. First, that dust may be contaminated by mycotoxins excreted by the fungi. Second, the conidia (and spores fragments) contain toxic metabolites which become airborne by propagation (Fischer and Dott, 2003). Major toxins detected in airborne dusts and bioaerosols have for the most part been trichothecenes of Stachybotrys chartarum, aflatoxins of Aspergillus flavus and metabolites of A. Fumigatus (Fischer and Dott, 2003). However, recent investigations in the potential of distinct species producing mycotoxins on seminatural substrates indicates that compounds in addition to those already found in native bioaerosols may occur.

Farm work has been especially hazardous. During the harvesting and handling of maize, dust concentrations of up to 107 ng of aflatoxin per m3 of air were reached, whereas granulated shells from peanuts contained 250–400 ng of aflatoxin per gram of shell (Sorenson et al., 1984). Grain handling was even more toxic, with aflatoxin B1 found in concentrations of up to 4849 ng/m3 (Sorenson et al., 1984).

Similar or even higher levels of exposure to microfungi compounds can be found in waste-handling facilities; and strains of A. flavusisolated in situ proved to be at least partly toxigenic (Déportes et al., 1997). However, there have been clinical reports on human cases of toxicosis due to Stachybotrys chartarum. Symptoms observed in patients stricken by Stachybotrys spp. include coughing, rhinitis, sore throat, nose bleeds, moderate fever, diarrhea, headaches, dermatitis, fatigue and general malaise (Schiefer, 1994). Inhalation exposure to mycotoxins has been suggested to cause acute kidney failure (ochratoxin), damage to both the central nervous system (tremorgenic mycotoxins), and the upper respiratory tract (Stachybotrys chartarum) (Miller, 1994).

Aerosolized fungal spores and volatile mycotoxins as potential health hazards: (a) residential indoor environments, (b) hospitals and (c) waste-handling industry and closed agricultural workplaces (e.g. composting facilities of farms) residential indoor environments—i: the concept of sick-building syndrome (SBS).

There is general agreement among scientists that both volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and microbial volatile organic compounds (MVOCs) are contaminants that lead to SBS. In experiments with humans exposed to VOC mixtures, exposure caused irritation of the eyes and upper respiratory tract, and inflammatory reactions, among other symptoms (Wiesmüller, 1998). In buildings with visible fungal growth, compounds such as dimethyldisulfide, 2-methyl-1-butanol, 1-octen-3-ol, and isobutyl ether have been found in concentrations of 10–100 ng/m3 of air (Sorenson et al., 1984).

There is general consensus that concentrations of ≥50 ng/m3 of air indicate indoor mould contamination, with outdoor concentrations being normally ≤10 ng/m3 of air (Keller et al., 1998). In Germany, 0.3 ng/m3 of air has been set as the maximum tolerable level for indoor air. In the last few years, a general trend has been observed concerning different types of VOC and the levels of tolerance to VOCs in humans. A report of ochratoxin in house dust was published by Richard et al. (1999) where samples of dust collected from heating ducts yielded up to 1500 ppb of ochratoxin A.

Shoemaker and House (2006) analyzed patients complaining of indoor VOC exposure symptoms, who also reported water intrusion in the home or workplace and where there was visual identification of microbial amplification in the areas of intrusion. Acremonium, Alternaria, Aspergillus, Chaetomium, Monodictys, Penicillium, Stachybotrys, Taeniolella and Trichoderma species were isolated from samples taken at visual microbial amplification sites (Shoemaker and House, 2006). They analyzed the biochemical parameters in these patients during both ‘suspected’ indoor excerbation of their symptoms and treatment with the toxin-removing compound cholestyramine (Shoemaker and House, 2006). They found that levels of leptin and melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH) increased during sick-building exposure, indicating contribution of inflammatory pathways and hypothalamic circuits. Treatment with cholestyramine reduced the levels of leptin, MSH and matrix metalloprotease 9 (MMP-9) in those infected (Shoemaker and House, 2006). It was observed that airborne fungal spores carried only a fraction of the mycotoxins and other biologically active components that people occupying water-damaged buildings were exposed to. Concentrations of small fungal fragments carrying mycotoxins, antigens and other biologically active components exceeded spore concentrations by up to 320-fold (Górny et al., 2002). For example, concentrations of airborne trichothecenes carried on fungal fragments (smaller than intact conidia) were reported to exceed 1300 pg/m3 in water-damaged buildings (Brasel et al., 2005).

Van Lancker et al. (2008) evaluated and compared the in vitro production of MVOCs on malt extract agar, plasterboard and wallpaper. They isolated and identified five fungal strains from the walls of water-damaged houses. Some molds produced specific compounds independently of substrate, such as trichodiene from Fusarium sporotrichioides and aristolochene from Penicillium roqueforti (Van Lancker et al., 2008). Polizzi et al. (2009) investigated the presence of fungi and mycotoxins in 99 samples (air, dust, wallpaper, mycelium or silicone) collected in the mouldy interiors of seven water-damaged buildings, while sampling for VOCs at the same time. They found the mycotoxins were mainly roquefortine C, chaetoglobosin A and sterigmatocystin but roridin E, ochratoxin A, aflatoxin B1 and aflatoxin B2 were also detected (Polizzi et al., 2009).

sec.title: Residential indoor environments-II: fungi, mycotoxins, and ‘leukemia houses’
sec.p: Blank et al. (1968) prepared sequential extracts of Candida parapsilosis with different organic solvents. A sodium carbonate wash of the methanol extract showed carcinogenic activity in mice demonstrated by the appearance of six sarcomas at the injection sites of six animals. Carcinogenic activities in the lipid extracts of species of the genera Microsporum, Tricophyton, Epidermophyton and Scopulariopsis were observed to increase the appearance of sarcomas, and frequency of leukemias and lung tumors (Blank et al., 1968).

In 1970 and 1971, the pioneering studies of Aleksandrowicz and Smyk involved identifying abundance of indoor fungi, particularly A. flavus, in the so-called ‘leukaemia houses’ (Aleksandrowicz et al., 1970a,b; Aleksandrowicz and Smyk, 1971, 1973; Ochmański and Barabasz, 2000). Wray et al. (1975) published a series of studies documenting the importance of the relation between indoor fungal growth and residential clusters of leukemia. At the time, multiple cases of leukemia in unrelated individuals in the same house was an extremely rare phenomenon, which demanded further investigation. Such an event occurred in Southern Georgia, where 4 victims, 3 occupants and a daily visitor over a 2-year period were diagnosed with the disease (Wray et al., 1975). A 36-year-old woman with the disease was the aunt of the 5-year-old boy, who was also effected, but none of the known genetic diseases predisposing them to leukemia were present, and there were no other kinship ties between the 2 other patients. Measurement of radiation levels in the home were deemed normal. Wray et al. (1975) isolated fungi from this ‘leukemia house’ believing that mycotoxin-producing strains might be present. They identified 110 strains of 21 common genera in samples taken from the house and its surroundings (Wray et al., 1975). Aflatoxin-producing Aspergillus parasiticus was also isolated from the samples. Similar genera were isolated from houses not associated with leukemia clusters at the similar rates as infected homes with the exception of Trichoderma, Verticillium and Monotospora, which were found in fewer of the control houses (less than 4 found in an indoor survey of 157 homes) (Wray et al., 1975). From these only Trichoderma was isolated in several sites in and around the ‘leukemia’ house but was not found in any of the control houses. Wray et al. (1979) then returned focus on the home of a husband and wife who had both developed acute myelomonocytic leukemia. The husband a 69-year-old white, retired textile worker developed acute myelomonocytic leukemia first, while his wife received medical attention 5 months after his diagnosis, receiving a diagnosis of acute undifferentiated leukemia. During her final relapse, it was discovered that her peripheral and bone marrow blasts had developed myelomonocytic morphology. Wray et al. (1979) collected fungus from the couple’s house and assayed for the isolated fungi effects on the in vivo response to phytohemagglutinin in guinea pigs. Skin responses to intradermal phytohemagglutinin were measured following injections of sterile fungal extracts. Penicillium canescens, Curvularia, Fusarium sambucinum, Fusarium equiseti and Trichoderma koningii were isolated and their isolates depressed the response to phytohemagglutinin, but the fungal isolates obtained from a nearby control house had failed to do so (Wray et al., 1975).

In 1976, a 42-year-old biochemist and his 28-year-old graduate student who had been working with purified aflatoxins for over a year, both developed adenocarcinoma of the colon within 3 months (Deger, 1976). Van Nieuwenhuize, et al. analyzed the frequency of neoplasia over 11 years in factory workers exposed to chronic low levels of aflatoxin during production of peanut and flaxseed oils (Wray et al., 1979). The exposed group, receiving an estimated dose of 165–195 μg of aflatoxins, showed a significant increase in several types of cancer when compared to a control group of the same age. Workers exposed to aerosols from Stachybotrys-infected substrate absorbed enough toxin via the respiratory route to develop blood dyscrasias (Wray et al., 1979).

sec.title: Fungal spores in hospital buildings and in hospital outbreaks’ of fungal infection
sec.p: In hospital operating theaters, patient rooms, and the corridors of wards, intensive measures are undertaken to maintain air hygiene, attempting to reduce airborne fungal spores to almost zero. Outbreaks of nosocomial aspergillosis in hospitals are often associated with activities such as, new construction, renovation and site excavation. Aisner et al. (1976) described aspergillus infections in cancer patients associated with the installation of new fireproofing materials in the hospital. An association between concentrations of A. Fumigatusand A. flavusexceeding 1 colony-forming unit (CFU) per m3 in oncology wards and an increased incidence of aspergillosis has also been discussed (Arnow et al., 1991).

In 1983, when a new hospital opened in Chicago, Illinois, environmental culturing of Aspergillus and surveillance for nosocomial aspergillosis cases illustrated the relationship between environmental contamination and infection. Monthly air sampling demonstrated increasing concentrations of A. flavus and A. fumigatus to mean levels greater than 1 CFU/m3 during 1986–1987. This was accompanied by a progressive increase in the incidence of aspergillosis in 1.2% of immunocompromised patients (Arnow et al., 1991). This prompted an inspection revealing heavy growth of Aspergillus organisms on air filters in the hospital. Removal of the contaminated filters and improved environmental maintenance resulted in a reduction in A. flavus and A. fumigatus to 0.01 CFU/m3 and a fourfold decline in aspergillosis incidence over the next 2 years. In immunocompromised patients, even numbers below 10 CFU/m3 thermotolerant aspergilli have been discussed as health hazards, since aspergillosis is fatal in more than 50% of cases despite appropriate treatment (Arnow et al., 1991). Brincker et al. (1991) reported a nosocomial epidemic of pulmonary aspergillosis occurred in a hematological ward during renovations to the interior of the building (Brincker et al., 1991). In an investigation carried out in the wards of a hospital in the United Arab Emirates, spore numbers of up to 25 CFU/m3 of air for A. fumigatuswere classified as low. Such high levels are questionable, even if thermotolerant species are more likely to be present in desert countries (Jaffal et al., 1997). Thuler et al. (1997) described an outbreak of 24 cases of Hansenula anomala infection in an oncological hospital in Rio de Janeiro, with the most frequent primary disease of the affected patients being leukemia (63%).

sec.title: Workplace associated risk of fungal volatile toxins: waste-handling industrial places and composting facilities of farms
sec.p: Fischer et al. (2000) conducted a study to assess differentiated exposure of both airborne fungi and fungal secondary metabolites on different work areas in a compost facility. They investigated the potential for production of mycotoxins and nonvolatile secondary metabolites in approximately 250 freshly isolated strains. Among the 11 most relevant species, viz. A. flavus, A. fumigatus, A. niger, A. parasiticus, A. versicolor, Emericella nidulans, Paecilomyces variotii, Penicillium brevicompactum, P. clavigerum, P. crustosum and P. cyclopium as well, 37 other metabolites of partially toxicological relevance were identified (Fischer et al., 2000). In an extract of dust and bioaerosols from the compost pile hall, they encountered tryptoquivaline and trypacidin, which were produced by all strains of A. fumigatuswhen investigated in pure cultures. 2-Methylfurane, α-pinene, camphene and limonene were also among the volatiles that occurred during each season and at every sampling site (Fischer et al., 2000).

The level of opportunistic thermotolerant fungi in the breathe of air workers has become a matter of discussion, as the number of workplaces in the waste-handling industry increases and emissions of microorganisms from these facilities are being critically evaluated. In addition to A. fumigatus and A. niger, Aspergillus terreus, A. flavus, Emericella nidulans, Aspergillus niveus, Aspergillus restrictus and Eurotium amstelodamiare all potentially pathogenic to humans. In waste-handling facilities, extremely high concentrations of (up to 107 CFU/m3 of air) thermotolerant fungi have been found (Fischer and Dott, 2003). Long-term exposure to living or dead particles containing fungal toxins, for example aflatoxins, gliotoxin, ochratoxin, patulin and trichothecenes, is expected to eventually suppress or modulate the immune response in healthy people. Investigations conducted with farm workers showed that increased exposure to dust contaminated with mycotoxins could lead to hepatocellular carcinoma and mycotoxicoses of the lungs (Ghio and Roggli, 1995). The occurrence of mycotoxins from A. fumigatusin native dusts and bioaerosols sampled in a composting facility was also demonstrated (Fischer et al., 1999).

sec.title: General descriptions of volcanic tuff and tuff minerals, zeolite clinoptilolite and clay montmorillonite
sec.p: Volcanic tuff, from the Italian tufo, is a type of rock consisting of consolidated volcanic ash ejected from vents during eruption. The crystal structure and characteristics of clays and zeolites are well established. As a general comment, both mineral groups are crystalline aluminosilicates formed by SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedra- and octahedra-sharing oxygen atoms to form three-dimensional structural networks (Chávez et al., 2010). In zeolite minerals, the structural arrangements develop channels through which ions pass, are adsorbed, retained, or exchanged, according to the characteristics and dimensions of channels and ions. This process defines the suitability of zeolite for specific adsorptions (Chávez et al., 2010). In the clay minerals, rings of SiO4 and AlO4 tetrahedra share oxygen atoms with Al(OH)O4 octahedra, developing layered structures with internal active surfaces and edges on which the ions are adsorbed (Chávez et al., 2010). The interlayer spaces in clays could be more suitable to separate larger and more complex ones than the internal channels of the zeolites.

Clinoptilolite is a natural zeolite/volcanic tuff mineral comprising a microporous arrangement of silica and alumina tetrahedral. It consists of a complex formula: (Na, K, Ca)2-3Al3(Al,Si)2Si13O36·12(H2O) (Oguz et al., 2000). Natural zeolites are microporous, aluminosilicate minerals, which form via the reaction of volcanic rocks, ash layers and alkaline groundwater. They are in the family of tektoalumosilicates since they possess an infinite three-dimensional cage-like structure (Oguz et al., 2000).

Montmorillonite is a very soft phyllosilicate group of minerals that typically form in microscopic crystals, forming a clay. It is named after Montmorillon in France. Montmorillonite is the main constituent of the volcanic ash weathering product, bentonite (Senturk et al., 2009). Montmorillonite is also a member of the smectite family (Senturk et al., 2009). The main product’s bentonite surface is hydrophilic in nature because inorganic cations, such as Na+ and Ca2+, are strongly hydrated in the presence of water. As a result, the adsorption efficiency of natural bentonite for organic molecules is low (Senturk et al., 2009). The adsorption properties of bentonite can be improved by the modification of the clay mineral surface with a cationic surfactant.

The cationic surfactants, also known as quaternary amine salts, take the form of (CH3)3NR+, where R is an alkyl hydrocarbon chain (Senturk et al., 2009). Replacement of inorganic exchangeable cations with cationic surfactants, converts the hydrophilic silicate surface of clay minerals to a hydrophobic surface and the complex obtained from this process is given the name organoclay (Senturk et al., 2009). As a result, an organoclay complex is an excellent adsorbent material for the removal of phenolic compounds, other organic contaminants and heavy metals from aqueous solutions (Senturk et al., 2009). Due to the small particle size (<2.0 μm), these natural geological products have a vast surface area (hundreds of square meters per gram of clay) with high concentrations of ions and compounds located on the surfaces to aid in the absorption process.

sec.title: Volcanic tuff’s toxic substance adsorption efficacy
sec.p: Dacovic et al. (2005) studied the adsorption of mycotoxins, ochratoxin and aflatoxin B1 by volcanic tuffs. They showed that volcanic tuff was capable of adsorbing ionizable ochratoxin mostly in cationic form (Dacovic et al., 2005). In regard to the nonionizable low polar aflatoxin B1, volcanic tuff also had a high affinity for adsorption.

The same group studied the adsorption of another mycotoxin zearalenone in natural zeolitic tuff, modified with different numbers of octadecyl-dimethyl-benzylammonium (ODMBA) ions (Daković et al., 2007). The results of solid-state 1H NMR analysis of the starting material suggested that zeolitic tuff is rich in mineral clinoptilolite (Daković et al., 2007). Three organozeolites (OZ-2, OZ-5 and OZ-10) were prepared with ODMBA surface coverages of 20, 50 and 100 mmol/100 g. Adsorption of zearalenone by organozeolites was best represented by a linear type of isotherm at pH 3, while at pH 7 and 9 adsorption of zearalenone by organozeolites followed a nonlinear (Langmuir) type of isotherm (Daković et al., 2007).

Marañón et al. (2006) studied the potential of the volcanic tuff from the Maramures district in Romania for use as an agent to remove ammonium from aqueous solution. Adsorption capacities of 19 mg NH4+/g were obtained in multicomponent solutions (containing NH4+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Ca2+, Na2+) (Marañón et al., 2006).

sec.title: Modified volcanic tuff’s disinfecting/antibacterial properties
sec.p: De la Rosa-Gómez et al. (2008) studied the potential for disinfection of water with the use of silver-modified clinoptilolite-heulandite-rich tuff (ZSAg, natural Mexican zeolite from Sonora). The team used Escherichia coli (ATCC 8739) and total coliform microorganisms, as indicators of microbiological contamination of water, to mimic the disinfection of synthetic or municipal wastewater (De la Rosa-Gómez et al., 2008). The antibacterial activity of the ZSAg as a bactericide was measured by the coliform concentration and exerted significant antibacterial efficacy (De la Rosa-Gómez et al., 2008).

sec.title: Clinoptilolite’s fungal toxin neutralizing efficacy in vivo
sec.p: Oguz et al. (2000) showed that clinoptilolite incorporated into the diet of broiler chickens (at 1.5 and 2.5%) reduced the deleterious effects of 2.5 mg total aflatoxin per kilogram of the birds’ feed. The single addition of clinoptilolite to the now aflatoxin-free diet also had no adverse effects on birds. Nistiar et al. (2000) studied the effect of clinoptilolite-rich zeolite on rumen microbiota on organophosphate-poisoned sheep. Nistiar’s group showed detrimental effects of these phosphates, particularly on rumen lipolytic bacteria, on the animals (Nistiar et al., 2000). Interestingly, clinoptilolite-rich zeolite was partly capable of reversing the damage to beneficial microbiota.

sec.title: Clinoptilolite’s toxic substance adsorption efficacy
sec.p: Clinoptilolite is capable of adsorbing toxic compounds such as barium (Chavez et al., 2010) and phenol (Sprynskyy et al., 2009). Using clinoptilolite rock, containing about 75% of clinoptilolite, originating from the Ukraine, Sprynskyy’s preliminary investigation of the clinoptilolite by low-temperature nitrogen adsorption illustrated that transcarpathian clinoptilolite may be a natural micro-mesoporous material that effectively adsorbs phenol (Sprynskyy et al., 2009).

sec.title: Montmorillonite’s toxic substance adsorption efficacy
sec.p: Kurtbay et al. (2008) studied the potencies of bentonite, nonylammonium bentonite, dodecylammonium bentonite, KSF-montmorillonite and chitosan bead, for a potential application in clearing the wine of ochratoxin A.

Their results revealed that in wine the removal of ochratoxin A succeeded at rates of 60–100% using KSF-montmorillonite. The highest adsorption capacity of ochratoxin A for red wine was obtained using 250 mg of KSF-montmorillonite, which also caused less damage to the wine and did not adsorb most of the beneficial polyphenols and anthocyanidins. Gianotti et al. (2008) showed that montmorillonite is capable of adsorbing and sequestering the organic pollutant 2,4,6-trichloroaniline from wastewaters by converging and diverging mechanisms within the adsorbent kaolinite.

Senturk et al. (2009) studied the efficacy of a cationic surfactant (cetyl trimethylammonium bromide), a modified natural bentonite from Tirebolu (Giresun, Turkey), as an adsorbent that removes phenol from aqueous solutions. They found that the adsorption of phenol by organobentonite was feasible, spontaneous and exothermic in temperatures ranging from 0 to 40°C.

Akçay and Akçay (2004) conducted research on the potential for organophilic bentonite (dodecylammonium bentonite) to adsorb p-chlorophenol and p-nitrophenol from aqueous solutions. The dodecylammonium (DDA)-bentonite exerted a strong adsorption activity but with a higher preference for absorbing p-nitrophenol (Akçay and Akçay, 2004).

Alkaram et al. (2009) from Iraq also studied the potential of natural bentonite to remove phenol from aqueous solutions. For this study, they used hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (HDTMA) and phenyltrimethylammonium bromide (PTMA) as modifier surfactants, showing that the adsorption of phenol with either HDTMA- or PTMA-modified bentonite was carried out in a spontaneously endothermic process (Alkaram et al., 2009).

sec.title: Direct antifungal activity of unmodified montmorillonite
sec.p: Lavie and Stotzky (1986a) drew attention to the limited nature of scientific studies of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. The fungus, which is pathogenic to humans, had at this point, only been isolated from soils that did not contain montmorillonite (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986a). In a series of elegant studies, they showed that montmorillonite exerted multiple antifungal mechanisms on Histoplasma (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986a). Illustrating that the respiration levels of three phenotypes of Histoplasma capsulatum was markedly reduced by low concentrations of montmorillonite.

Scanning electron microscopy after extensive washing also showed that montmorillonite particles were tightly bound to hyphae, suggesting that the clays reduced fungus respiration by adhering to the mycelial surface and thereby interfered with the movement of nutrients, metabolites, and gases (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986a). Further studies revealed that montmorillonite reduction of Histoplasma respiration also interfered with the ability of the fungus to gain nutrition from iron (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986b). This interference was the result of the montmorillonite adsorption of the fungus’ iron-transporting siderophore (deferricoprogen B). The addition of foreign siderophores partially alleviated this reduction in respiration (Lavie and Stotzky, 1986b).

sec.title: Montmorillonite’s fungal toxin neutralizing efficacy
sec.p: Abdel-Wahhab et al. (1998) analyzed the effects of bentonite and hydrated sodium calcium alumin-silicate (HSCAS) on experimental aflatoxicosis. They added both bentonite and HSCAS at a level of 0.5% (w/w) to the feed containing 2.5 mg aflatoxins per kg of feed and fed the mixture to mature male rats for 15 successive days (Abdel-Wahhab et al., 1998). Aflatoxin alone significantly decreased feed intake and altered serum biochemical parameters of liver and kidney functions, causing chromosomal aberrations in the bone marrow cells of the rats (Abdel-Wahhab et al., 1998). Bentonite or HSCAS alone did not alter any of these parameters, yet when added to aflatoxin-contaminated feed, they were capable of reversing the deleterious effects of aflatoxin (Abdel-Wahhab et al., 1998).

Desheng et al. (2005) also studied montmorillonite’s potential to adsorb aflatoxin B1 in vitro. In an aqueous solution, montmorillonite was capable of adsorbing aflatoxin B1 up to 600 μg/g. In subsequent in vivoexperiments, they demonstrated that montmorillonite, when added to the feed of broiler chickens at 0.5%, significantly diminished the adverse effects in the chickens feeding up to 200 μg of aflatoxin B1/kg (Desheng et al., 2005).

Santurio et al. (1999) in another study, evaluated the protective effect of natural sodium bentonite on chickens consuming aflatoxins in their feed. In comparison to chickens that received only aflatoxin (3 mg/kg food), adding sodium bentonite at 5 g/kg to the feed of the aflatoxin-receiving chickens improved body weights by 31.3% at 42 days of age, increased food intake by 23.8% and improved productive efficiency in the birds by 40.1% (Santurio et al., 1999).

Abdel Wahhab et al. (2005) investigated the efficacy of Egyptian montmorillonite, to adsorb sterigmatocystin, which is both closely related to mycotoxin aflatoxin and is a precursor in aflatoxin biosynthesis. Their results showed that montmorillonite was able to adsorb sterigmatocystin at levels as high as 97.8% in aqueous solutions (Abdel Wahhab et al., 2005). The team conducted in vivo experiments with Nile tilapia fish that received an intragastric dose of montmorillonite in corn oil (0.5 mg/kg of body weight) with or without sterigmatocystin (1.6 μg/kg of body weight) twice a week for 4 weeks (Abdel Wahhab et al., 2005). The intragastric administration of montmorillonite combined with sterigmatocystin resulted in a reduction in the number of micronucleated red blood cells and the frequency of chromosomal aberrations in the kidney when compared to sterigmatocystin alone (Abdel Wahhab et al., 2005).

Carson and Smith (1983) conducted a study to track bentonite’s potential to reverse the toxicity of fungal T-2 toxin. T-2 is a trichothecene mycotoxin, a naturally occurring mold by-product found in the Fusariumspp. fungus, which is toxic to both humans and animals. The male weanling rats were fed with diets containing one of bentonite, anion exchange resin, cation exchange resin or vermiculite hydrobiotite, at levels of 5%. Each diet was fed to the rats twice, once with 3 μg T-2 toxin/g of feed for 2 weeks and once without the toxin (Carson and Smith, 1983). The bentonite and anion exchange resins treatments were the most successful at overcoming growth depression and feed refusal caused by ingestion of the T-2 toxin. Bentonite fed at 10% was the most effective treatment in overcoming feed refusal and growth depression (Carson and Smith, 1983). In radioactive trace studies, the rats feed were dosed with a 0%, 5%, 7.5% or 10% bentonite solution for 2 weeks and then dosed the rats with [3H] T-2 toxin. They collected urine and feces for 21 h after dosing and excised tissues for determination of residual 3H. Significant increases in fecal excretion of 3H were shown, when the feeding of bentonite was compared with the casein-based, semi-purified control diet (Carson and Smith, 1983). All concentrations of bentonite tested reduced residual 3H in muscle. The results clearly showed that bentonite significantly cleared a common fungal toxin from the animals’ systems via increasing fecal elimination (Carson and Smith, 1983).

sec.title: Direct antimicrobial efficacy of unmodified, natural volcanic mineral clays
sec.p: Haydel et al. (2008) reviewed the use of the two clay minerals, CsAgO2 and CsArO2, as a therapeutic treatment of Buruli ulcer. Both CsAgO2 and CsArO2 are iron-rich smectite and illite clay minerals enriched with a solution of either both magnesium and potassium or calcium (please note that montmorillonite is also a smectite) (Haydel et al., 2008). They suggested that these natural nanomaterials could have significant effects on both infectious bacteria and wound healing (Haydel et al., 2008). In their study, they explained that in 2001, a French humanitarian aid worker in the Ivory Coast of Africa began treating children with Buruli ulcers using a solution comprising these two clay minerals (CsAgO2 and CsArO2) (Brunet de Courrsou, 2002). Within days of initiating treatment with clay poultices, a rapid, nonsurgical debridement of the destroyed tissue occurred. Extended treatment with clay minerals resulted in continued debridement of the ulcer, tissue regeneration, and wound healing (Brunet de Courrsou, 2002). Haydel et al. highlighted the importance of these therapeutic observations: explaining that, while antibiotics have been effective for the treatment of pre-ulcerative lesions, it has generally been unsuccessful in the treatment of ulcerative form of Buruli ulcer disease, caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans (van der Werf et al., 1999). To ascertain the underlying mechanisms, Haydel et al. (2008) studied the effects of these clays on a variety of bacteria, finding that one mineral, CsAgO2, demonstrated bactericidal activity against pathogenic E. coli, extended-spectrum β-lactamase (ESBL) E. coli, Salmonella enterica serovar typhimurium, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Mycobacterium marinum. CsAgO2 also exerted a combined bacteriostatic/bactericidal effect against Staphylococcus aureus, Penicillin-resistant S. aureus, methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) and Mycobacterium smegmatis (Haydel et al., 2008).

sec.title: Modified montmorillonite’s disinfecting/antibacterial properties
sec.p: Nováková (1977) suggested that bentonite was capable of adsorbing bacteria and the occurrence of this absorbance was much stronger for nonmotile gram-positive spore-forming bacteria than motile gram-negative rods. Interestingly, the motile bacteria adhered to bentonite clays only in phases of rapid multiplication (Nováková, 1977). This might indicate an opportunity to entrap and destroy growing bacteria with antiseptic drugs conjugated with modified montmorillonites (Nováková, 1977).

Herrera et al. (2000) analyzed the potential of cationic surfactant cetylpyridinium-modified clays in aiding the removal of bacteria from aqueous solutions. During the initial study, screening various cetylpyridinium-exchanged products for potential antibacterial activity, three cetylpyridinium-exchanged clays, acid-activated montmorillonite, Ca2+-montmorillonite, and Na+-montmorillonite proved to be the most effective (Herrera et al., 2000). One milligram of each montmorillonite was added to a solution containing Salmonella enteritidis at a concentration of 40,000 CFUs/ml. The clays reduced the bacterial numbers at very high rates between 95% and 98% (Herrera et al., 2000). On attempting to desorb cetylpyridinium from the modified clays by washing in sterile physiological saline for 24 h, the resulting wash solutions failed to produce any significant reduction in bacterial colony counts, while the washed clays retained their full antimicrobial activity (Herrera et al., 2000). Their findings suggest that the antibacterial effect of modified montmorillonite clays is localized on the clay’s surface and is not due to cetylpyridinium dissociating from the clay (Herrera et al., 2000). Interestingly, their electron microscopical analysis revealed that the bacteria adhered to the surface of the cetylpyridinium-exchanged montmorillonites but not the parent clays (Herrera et al., 2000). The investigators concluded that the mechanism by which the bacterial counts were reduced involved the enhanced hydrophobicity and affinity of the cetylpyridinium-exchanged montmorillonite for Salmonella, as well as the direct antibacterial activity of cetylpyridinium (Herrera et al., 2000).

He et al. (2006) synthesized novel organoclays via combining Ca-montmorillonite with chlorhexidine acetate via ion exchange. Strikingly, the resulting organoclay exerted a long-term antibacterial activity which lasted for a year (He et al., 2006). The antibacterial activity of organoclays strongly depended on their absorption ability to bacteria. The increase in chlorhexidine acetate loading led to an increase in the organoclay hydrophobicity, which in turn improved the affinity between the organoclays and E. coli, since the cell walls of the viable bacteria are usually negatively charged due to functional groups such as carboxylates present in lipoproteins at their surface (He et al., 2006).

Ma and Guo (2007) studied the bactericidal activity and mechanism of Cu2+-loaded montmorillonite (Cu-MMT). Their results revealed that Cu-MMT was strongly efficient against E. coli, with a minimum inhibitory concentration of 0.16 mg/ml and a minimum bactericidal concentration of 0.64 mg/ml (Ma and Guo, 2007). Hong and Rhim (2008) studied the antimicrobial activity of organically modified montmorillonite nano-clays (Cloisite 20A and Cloisite 30B) against four representative pathogenic bacteria (S. aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella typhimurium and E. coli O157:H7). Cloisite 30B showed the highest antibacterial activity by inactivating the gram-positive bacteria completely within an hour of incubation and inactivating the gram-negative bacteria by more than 2–3 log cycles after 8 h of incubation (Hong and Rhim, 2008). Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of cell structure indicated that the organically modified nano-clays caused rupture of the membranes of bacterial cells (Hong and Rhim, 2008).

Wang et al. (2008) prepared quaternized chitosan—organic montmorillonite nanocomposites, characterizing their physicochemical and antimicrobial properties. They prepared quaternized chitosan/layered silicate nanocomposites by simple solution mixing in aqueous media. Their antimicrobial studies revealed that the nanocomposites strongly inhibited the growth of a wide variety of microorganisms, including gram-positive bacteria, gram-negative bacteria, and fungi (Wang et al., 2008). As the amount of montmorillonite increased, the nanocomposites had a better inhibitory effect on microorganisms, especially gram-positive bacteria (Wang et al., 2008). The lowest minimum inhibition concentration (MIC) value of their nanocomposites against S. aureus and Bacillus subtilis were less than 0.00313% (w/v) under all conditions (Wang et al., 2008).

sec.title: Suggestions about how and where to use the volcanic materials, tuff, clinoptilolite and montmorillonite in internal architecture
sec.p: At this point, we would like to illustrate some examples of how and where volcanic minerals could be used in the construction of the interior spaces of buildings. One possibility is to use them in exterior cladding (as concrete panels), to maintain water impermeability, since volcanic minerals are rich in silicium and would increase water resistance in the concrete. However, it is important to remember the above mentioned physical properties of montmorillonite. Natural montmorillonite is rich in sodium and calcium, which strongly hydrates in the presence of water. This would require the removal of inorganic exchangable cations with cationic surfactants which would convert the hydrophilic surface of the clay to a hydrophobic surface. In order to use montmorillonite to effectively block water permeability, only cationic surfactant-modified montmorillonite could be used. By blocking water permeability, the risk of mold production at the interior sides of the walls is lowered.

A second possibility would employ these minerals in suture mortars between wall tiles. Since tile is often used in wet and humid environments (such as bathrooms), the mortar in the grout constitutes a suitable place for mold growth. By mixing volcanic minerals with this mortar, the mold growth may be blocked.

Volcanic minerals could also be mixed directly into the slab concrete between underfloor heating and parquet. With steam pressure coming from the ground, wetness and heat provide a proper environment for the mold growth on the slab concrete under the parquet. Such a mixture may make the slab an unsuitable surface for mold growth. This process already occurs to some extent with montmorillonite/bentonite being mixed with some concrete types at ratios between 3% and 5% to increase the processability but not for its antifungal properties.

The use of these minerals in ventilation ducts as filters is also possible. Since some of these volcanic minerals bear inherent antibacterial activity, and others could be easily chemically modified to bear strong antibacterial potentials, they may block bacterial growth in ventilation channels. It may be possible that volcanic minerals could block the growth of the deadly bacteria Legionella which lives in air conditioning and ventilation systems. However, an immediate use of volcanic minerals would be to limit the spread of infection through hospital ventilation systems. As outlined above, hospital ventilation systems are a significant source of hospital fungemias. For example, as explained above, Aspergillus infections in immunocompromised patients may stem from hospital ventilation systems. Volcanic tuff, montmorillonite and clinoptilolite all possess strong antifungal activity when modified; and with montmorillonite’s inherent antifungal potential, it could be considered a perfect substituent for us in hospital ventilation channels.

Beyond ventilation systems (the antibacterial activities of modified tuff and montmorillonite and direct antibacterial activity of some close-montmorillonite relative smectite clays), these materials could be directly mixed into the concrete used to build hospital walls, possibly aiding in the creation of inherently antibacterial hospital environments.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: VOCs, especially mycotoxins in bioaerosols constitute a significant health problem. They could pose health hazards in residential indoor environments (for instance, SBS and leukemia houses). The danger lies not only in their toxins, as whole fungi can also cause in-hospital fungemia. Fungi can also be the cause of occupation-associated cancer epidemics, especially in the waste handling industry and in closed agricultural workplaces. As explained above, workers involved in the production of peanut and flaxseed oils could be exposed to significant levels of aflatoxins.

It is possible to employ volcanic minerals and clays, volcanic tuff, clinoptilolite and montmorillonite as a protection against these hazards via mixing these materials with building concrete or mortar, while benefiting from their fungal toxin neutralizing efficacy, and in the case of montmorillonite from their direct antifungal action. Modified tuff and montmorillonite (as well as some smectites, montmorillonite’s close relative) also possesses strong antibacterial efficacy. Mixing these volcanic clays with hospital wall concrete may help to create an antibacterial environment in hospital buildings.
